stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on overworld/hub environment polish (terrain blending, rock/sand/grass transitions, shaders/decals, and choosing a volcanic-vs-nonvolcanic rock language for an island area). He mentions newly integrated ambient SFX enabled by a fully remade sound engine, shares that Course 4 received its first beta test (positive reception but a serious softlock and a weak plane mission), and introduces a public RTYI progress-tracker spreadsheet while reiterating there is no release date.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a public progress tracker, reports first Course 4 beta-test results, and confirms a major underlying tech change (sound engine remake) enabling broader SFX/ambience work.

findings.summary: Kaze says the sound engine was "completely remade," which now makes it feasible to add ambient sound effects broadly throughout the game; he demonstrates newly imported SFX from Badub (e.g., propeller and windmill ambience) and notes they make scenes feel more alive even if players don’t consciously notice them.
findings.quote: Now that the sound engine is completely remade, we can add some sound effects everywhere.

findings.summary: Course 4 has its first beta test; testers liked it more than Kaze expected, suggesting the level’s direction is working, but a major bug caused repeated softlocks and a specific mission (the plane mission) is considered poor and likely needs redesign.
Kaze plans to replace/redesign the Course 4 plane mission and says he already discussed a “damage control” approach with Biobak, implying an active iteration loop based on early playtest feedback.

Kaze created and shared a public "RTYI progress tracker" spreadsheet with per-course completion percentages (many courses shown in the mid-to-high 90s, some at ~75%, Course 4 at 25% after first beta). He intends to update it regularly and tweet it out.

Kaze pins/points viewers to the progress tracker as an answer to repeated release-date questions, reiterating the game will release "when it's done" and that constant release-date queries have become a chronic annoyance.
findings.quote: It's going to release when it's done, basically.

findings.summary: Overworld visual direction: Kaze iterates on terrain blending with transparent decals ("decal with Red X Alpha") and discusses adding hue/temperature transitions at higher elevations (e.g., making top areas more bluish/desaturated).
Kaze is blocked by a Fast64 tool bug (lighting/scene issues and a “lighthouse” problem) and indicates he cannot fix it in-project; he is waiting on Fast64 to address it.
findings.quote: This is a Fast64 bug. They need to fix the program.

findings.summary: Environment art decision for a volcanic island: he explores multiple rock textures and, after considering realism vs Mario readability, decides the best move is to shorten cliff faces and put grass on top to keep the island "friendly" and Yoshi-like, then prevent reaching those areas via collision/layout rather than making cliffs look unapproachable.
findings.quote: It's going to look a lot more friendly, which is important for Yoshi's Islands.

findings.summary: Kaze decides the island should visually separate into a volcanic side and a non-volcanic side (different rock treatments) and then unify them through color matching and better transitions/decals.
He mentions wanting the final build to work on “Overdrive” (likely EverDrive/flashcart) and believes he can fix the crash cause, though he can’t fully promise it yet.
findings.quote: I do plan on figuring out why the overdrive crashes... I am feeling fairly confident that I can fix it.

findings.summary: Biobak’s “reworks” are described as mostly graphics updates (~90%) with small, easy-to-accommodate gameplay tweaks; Kaze also notes Course 3 could be reworked again if Biobak wants changes.

Kaze describes a bootleg resale ecosystem around ROM hacks: he says preventing flashable ROMs is difficult, and if not prevented, bootleggers sell repro cartridges; he speculates his earlier work may have generated very large revenue for bootleggers and worries about Nintendo misattributing that activity to him.
findings.quote: There's probably... an entire industry for that.

findings.summary: Kaze frames his preference for focusing deeply on one hardware generation (like N64) rather than constant new hardware cycles, arguing it could lead to better/cheaper/more games and clearer creative exploration of constraints.
findings.quote: Can we just stop and just explore one hardware?

biobak.summary: Kaze says he coordinated with Biobak about addressing Course 4’s plane mission issues (a “damage control” plan), showing Biobak is involved in responding to playtest results, not only visuals.

Kaze indicates Course 3 may receive yet another pass if Biobak wants changes, implying Biobak has strong influence on final-level presentation/polish decisions even after a course is considered playable.
Kaze clarifies to chat that a “Biobak rework” is primarily a graphics refresh (about 90%), with only minor gameplay adjustments for compatibility.

badub.summary: Kaze imports and starts using Badub’s sound effects for environmental ambience; these are now easier to integrate because the sound engine was rebuilt.
Kaze plays a newer overworld track that includes the game’s main theme and attributes broader audio work to Badub’s contributions (music/SFX).

findings.summary: Kaze says certain visuals will look much better once Firebike “gets his hands on this,” implying Firebike contributes to graphical polish/asset improvement in the pipeline.
Kaze references messaging Lyska about terminology/positioning of the “good PC port” (recompilation), suggesting ongoing community coordination around platform/support messaging.

A community member Kaze calls a “rock expert” provides geology-informed feedback on volcanic vs sedimentary appearance (layering/stripes, cliff-top flatness), directly influencing Kaze’s rock-texture selection and the decision to grass-cap cliffs for Yoshi-friendly readability.

memorable_quotes.quote: Now that the sound engine is completely remade, we can add some sound effects everywhere.
memorable_quotes.context: Explains a foundational tech upgrade that unlocks richer ambience and world “aliveness.”

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: It's going to release when it's done, basically.
memorable_quotes.context: His blunt stance on release timing and the pressure/annoyance of constant release-date questions.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze

memorable_quotes.context: Captures Kaze’s creative philosophy of committing to constraints (N64-era hardware) rather than chasing endless platform upgrades.

key_stories.title: Course 4 first beta test reveals a softlock and a weak mission
key_stories.summary: Kaze reports the first external beta test for Course 4. Feedback was more positive than he expected, but a serious softlock bug repeatedly blocked progress, and he concludes the plane mission is not working.
key_stories.challenge: Validate Course 4’s design and find issues early; manage a critical progression-stopping softlock and an unpopular mission concept.
key_stories.process: He reviews tester impressions, acknowledges the inevitability of bugs in a first test, and discusses a redesign/damage-control plan for the plane mission with Biobak.
key_stories.outcome: Course 4 direction is reaffirmed, but a bugfix and mission redesign are now prioritized before further testing.

key_stories.title: Publishing a progress tracker to manage expectations
key_stories.summary: After recurring questions about release timing, Kaze creates and shares a public spreadsheet showing per-course completion percentages. He plans to update it regularly and tweet it as a transparent progress signal.
key_stories.challenge: Community pressure for release dates and difficulty communicating progress in a long-running ROM-hack project.
key_stories.process: He builds a visible tracker, updates Course 4 to 25% after its first beta, and points viewers to it instead of giving a date.
key_stories.outcome: A new public artifact for documentary timeline-building, and a tool for Kaze to redirect “when release” questions.
key_stories.key_quote: If you want to track the progress in RTYI, you can look at this spreadsheet.

key_stories.title: Overworld volcanic island readability vs realism
key_stories.summary: While polishing the overworld’s island area, Kaze experiments with rock textures and consults chat’s geology feedback. He concludes that strict volcanic realism (dark gray/black) clashes with Mario/Yoshi readability and chooses a friendlier solution: grass-capped cliffs with controlled reachability.
key_stories.challenge: Make a volcanic environment that reads as Mario-like, matches the art style, and still feels geologically coherent without looking harsh or “unreachable.”
key_stories.process: He tests multiple textures, considers stripe/layer logic, proposes splitting the island into volcanic and non-volcanic sides, and decides to shorten cliffs and add grass on top while preventing access via design/collision.
key_stories.outcome: Clear art-direction decision: two-sided rock language + grass caps for warmth, with future work to improve transitions/decals and color matching.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe it is the right move to say, fuck the rocky parts. We're putting grass on top.

key_stories.title: Tooling bottleneck: Fast64 lighthouse/lighting bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze runs into a Fast64 issue affecting rendering/scene setup (including a lighthouse problem). He checks for fixes and concludes he’s blocked until the tool is updated.
key_stories.challenge: External tooling bug prevents needed environment work and/or correct export behavior.
key_stories.process: He checks Fast64 forums, tries workarounds, and ultimately defers the fix to the tool maintainers.
key_stories.outcome: Known dependency risk: art/level polish is partially gated by third-party tool stability.
key_stories.key_quote: This is a Fast64 bug. They need to fix the program.

key_stories.title: Bootleg cartridge economy and Nintendo risk anxiety
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains why allowing easy flashable-ROM paths can lead to bootleggers selling repro cartridges of ROM hacks. He claims there’s an industry doing this and worries Nintendo could associate him with sales he doesn’t control.
key_stories.challenge: Distribution and preservation vs protecting the project and avoiding legal exposure from third-party commercialization.
key_stories.process: He describes the difficulty of preventing flashable ROM use and the downstream incentive for bootleggers; he frames this as a practical, ongoing constraint for release decisions.
key_stories.outcome: A business/legal consideration shaping how RTYI might be released and what protections might be attempted.
key_stories.key_quote: If I don't prevent people from doing that, then people are going to make bootlegs of my game and sell them.

open_questions.context: Kaze says Course 4’s first beta revealed a “very frustrating” softlock that happened repeatedly, but he does not explain the cause.
questions: What exactly triggered the softlock (specific star/mission, object interaction, checkpoint/warp state)?
Was it a logic/state-machine issue, collision/warp, or mission scripting problem?
How do you reproduce it reliably, and what’s the planned fix?
Did this change your beta-testing checklist or tooling (debug displays, logging, savestate strategy)?

open_questions.topic: Replacing or redesigning the Course 4 plane mission
open_questions.context: Kaze says the plane mission “sucks” and he discussed “damage control” ideas with Biobak, but no concrete redesign is described.
questions: Why did the plane mission fail—controls, camera, pacing, readability, difficulty, or fun factor?
What replacement concepts are on the table (new objective, vehicle changes, or removing the plane entirely)?
How do you preserve the level’s theme/flow if the plane setpiece changes?
What did Biobak propose in the damage-control discussion?

open_questions.topic: Sound engine remake scope and timeline
open_questions.context: Kaze states the sound engine is “completely remade,” enabling SFX everywhere, but doesn’t detail what changed.
questions: What was wrong/limiting about the previous sound setup?
What did the remake involve (API redesign, sequence player, bank management, streaming, channels/priority)?
How does the new system support ambient loops, positional audio, and per-area SFX density without performance issues?
Who implemented which parts, and how long did it take?

open_questions.context: Kaze says the final build should work on “Overdrive” and he’s confident he can fix crashes, but provides no diagnosis.
questions: Which flashcart/hardware configurations crash (EverDrive model, expansion pak, region console)?
What symptoms occur (random crash, specific area load, audio/heap corruption)?
Is the issue timing-related, DMA/PI, memory alignment, or save handling?
What’s the test plan for real-hardware verification across builds?

open_questions.context: Kaze says he’s blocked by a Fast64 bug and can’t fix it in-project, but doesn’t name the exact defect or impact.
questions: What exactly is broken (vertex colors, light direction, material export, transform, display lists)?
How does it affect RTYI production (which assets/areas are blocked)?
What workaround attempts failed, and what would a tool fix need to do?
Have you considered switching parts of the pipeline away from Fast64 or pinning to a known-good version?

open_questions.topic: Progress tracker methodology and definitions of “% complete”
open_questions.context: Kaze shares a spreadsheet with per-course percentages and says many are near completion, but doesn’t define criteria.
questions: What qualifies a course as 100% (all stars implemented, polish pass, bugfixing, optimization, art rework done)?
Do percentages include reworks (e.g., Biobak graphics passes) or only initial completion?
What are the remaining 75% courses missing—missions, art, scripting, music, or QA?
How will you keep this tracker accurate without it becoming another time sink?

open_questions.topic: Biobak rework pipeline and review process
open_questions.context: Kaze says Biobak reworks are ~90% graphics and can prompt additional changes even when a course is “finished.”
questions: How do you coordinate reworks without breaking gameplay (asset naming, versioning, scene export rules)?
What’s the approval loop—does Kaze request changes, or does Biobak pitch improvements?
How often do graphics reworks necessitate collision/mission tweaks?
What’s the biggest rework surprise so far (time cost or cascading changes)?

open_questions.context: Kaze says preventing flashable ROMs is hard and bootleggers sell repro carts; he worries Nintendo could blame him.
questions: What concrete steps can/should you take to discourage bootlegs (patch-only distribution, license text, checks, encryption, cartridge-ID checks)?
How do you weigh accessibility/preservation against bootleg deterrence?
Has bootlegging impacted your release planning for RTYI compared to earlier projects?
Have you ever received any legal threats connected to third-party repro sales?

open_questions.topic: Volcanic island: narrative/gameplay plan for volcano activity
open_questions.context: Chat asks how active the volcano should be (erupting, lava cooling, story reason). Kaze doesn’t decide on-stream.
questions: Will the volcano be purely visual set dressing, or tied to missions/events (eruption setpiece, timed hazards)?
Does the “volcanic side vs normal side” split reflect story progression or world gating?
How do you keep hazards readable and fair while maintaining Yoshi-friendly tone?
What other overworld mechanics depend on this island’s final art direction?

open_questions.topic: Overworld ambience goals enabled by new SFX
open_questions.context: Kaze demonstrates subtle propeller/windmill audio and says it adds life, but doesn’t outline an overall ambience plan.
questions: What’s the target density of ambient SFX per area (and how do you avoid audio clutter)?
How are ambient sounds triggered (distance-based, camera-based, zone volumes)?
How much of this is authored by Badub vs assembled/placed by Kaze?
